Award.AwardTitle: In situ lipophile labeling in living cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry is funding Professors Jeffrey Arterburn, Charles B. Shuster, and Tanner Schaub of New Mexico State University to develop methods for labeling unsaturated lipids in the membranes of living cells with fluorescent dyes. To meet this challenge, a combined approach involving catalytic cross-metathesis coupling chemistry, live cell imaging and ultrahigh resolution mass spectrometry will be used. The aims are to synthesize useful lipid probes for imaging, and then characterize the labeling chemistry within the biological context of the cell membrane. The interdisciplinary methodology and research environment are well suited to the education of scientists at all levels, and continue the PI's efforts to promote participation of women and underrepresented minorities in science. The methodology will be employed outside the University setting in a boot camp for science journalists. The team will develop displays featuring "Chile Chemistry" to introduce chemistry and scientific principles to elementary school students during tours of the NMSU Chile Pepper Institute.

The identity and distribution of labeled lipids will be determined by ultrahigh resolution mass spectrometry and their localization and dynamic motion will be imaged using optical microscopy. The strategy of chemically modifying native unsaturated lipids by fluorescent dye attachment to produce optical imaging probes is new and complementary to existing strategies that utilize exogenous probes, bioorthogonal labeling, and direct spectroscopic methods to study membrane lipids. Aim 1 will optimize chemistry to synthesize useful lipid probes for live-cell imaging, evaluate metabolic alterations to the lipid probes, and label lipid extract mixtures to characterize the composition of unsaturated lipids as a basis for comparative analyses. Aim 2 will label specific lipids in live cells to investigate biological context of the cell membrane as a factor in selectivity. Additionally, the identity and distribution of dye-labeled lipids will be determined by ultrahigh resolution mass spectrometry and their localization and dynamic motion will be tracked by optical imaging. Aim 3 will use advanced fluorescence microscopy experiments to assess the membrane localization and the functionality of the CM-labeled lipids through short and long term observations. In the long term, the realization of this labeling methodology will provide a powerful analytical approach for fundamental studies of lipid localization, dynamics and determining the roles of discrete lipids in membrane biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Introduction: Lipids are a broad class of biologically important compounds including fats, oils, and are major components of cell membranes with many roles in structure, energy storage, and involvement in a wide variety of biophysical and biochemical processes. Certain lipids are essential for healthy human diet and nutrition, and biological sources of lipids serve as alternatives to petroleum feedstock for industrial processes and materials. The unsaturated alkene double bond is pivotal for lipid structure and function, and because these compounds are difficult to study, new methods for analyzing and identifying cellular lipids, and new scientific tools for studying the location and movement of individual lipids are needed. In this project we investigated cross metathesis reactions, exchanging alkene groups in unsaturated lipids with reagents, for the production of labeled lipid fragments that are easily detected and identified by sensitive optical and mass spectrometry techniques, and can be directly observed in living cells using confocal microscopy and super resolution imaging.

Intellectual Merit: We discovered a new class of alkenes activated by a sulfur dioxide group that exhibit enhanced cross metathesis reactivity. These reagents react with unsaturated lipids, including very sterically hindered alkenes, and we reported the first example of a cross metathesis with the most hindered alkene class: tetrasubstituted. We conducted computational studies that provided new insights and understanding of the enhanced reactivity of allylic chalcogenides, and perspective on otherwise perplexing examples of failed metathesis events. We have used these reagents for a one-step synthesis of lipid probes with bright dyes for sensitive separation, detection and quantification, and unique isotopic composition for unambiguous identification by ultrahigh resolution mass spectrometry. We were able to detect and quantify omega-3 fatty acids and distinguish omega-6 or omega-9 unsaturated fatty acids from lipid sources. The fluorescence emission properties of these dyes enables imaging applications in living cells. We synthesized membrane-derived phospholipid probes and found that they localized in the outer cellular membrane, and the dyes were photostable and bright for imaging and observation of dynamic processes using the super resolution radial fluctuation stream application with living cells. This synthetic approach for membrane-localization provides an alternative strategy for designing impermeable conjugates that rely on oligomeric dendrimers or large protein conjugates. The co-PI's involved in this project were able to further enhance the institutional research infrastructure by obtaining an extremely powerful Orbitrap Fusion mass spectrometer system with funding through the NSF Major Research Instrumentation Program, with sensitivity and dynamic range capabilities that are regionally unique. This project also stimulated acquisition of a second key major instrument: the Andor Dragonfly Olympus microscope imaging system equipped with multiple laser lines and capabilities for cutting edge experiments and single molecule super resolution imaging of lipids within the membrane.

Broader Impacts: This project involved the collaboration of three laboratories at a Minority Serving Institution with complementary areas of expertise in synthetic organic and analytical chemistry, and live-cell biological imaging, providing a dynamic research training environment and experiences for multiple graduate and undergraduate students, imparting valuable scientific knowledge and skills and stimulating continuing education to provide a diverse workforce. These students have already earned baccalaureate (3), masters (4) and doctoral (4) degrees at the time of this report, with more in progress. This project supported research experiences for Undergraduates (4); Graduates (13) included female (9) and underrepresented (3) groups; Postdoctoral and Technical staff (4) including female (1) and underrepresented (2) groups, and two of these individuals are now employed as faculty. PI Shuster has contributed significantly towards improving the effectiveness of communicating science to the public through his co-direction of the inquiry based Logan Science Journalism Program at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, MA, giving journalists hands-on exposure to biological research techniques related to the award.

Summary:  This project has enabled a multi-disciplinary collaboration resulting in the first intermolecular cross metathesis reaction of a tetrasubstituted alkene and new methods for generating fluorescent lipid probes, analytical methods for structural identification of lipids with unknown and regioisomeric composition, and new probes for super resolution imaging of lipids within the membrane in living cells.
